title: Roberto Galia
text:
Roberto Galia (; born 16 March 1963) is an Italian professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> coach and a former player, who played as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a> and as a <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>. Currently, he manages <a href="S.C.%20Insubria%20A.S.D.">Insubria</a>.
Club career.
Roberto Galia made his <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> debut with <a href="Como%20Calcio">Como</a> as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Full-back">fullback</a> on 10 May 1981, in a 1–0 home defeat to <a href="S.S.C.%20Napoli">Napoli</a>. He notably scored the decisive goal in a 2–1 against <a href="Bologna%20F.C.%201909">Bologna</a> which saved his club from relegation on the final match-day that <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20Serie%20A">season</a>, although the <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20Serie%20A">following season</a>, he was unable to save his club from <a href="1982%E2%80%9383%20Serie%20B">relegation</a>. He transferred to <a href="UC%20Sampdoria">Sampdoria</a> in 1983, where he spent three seasons as a permanent member of the starting line-up, winning the <a href="1984%E2%80%9385%20Coppa%20Italia">1984–85 Coppa Italia</a>. In 1986, he moved to Hellas Verona under Osvaldo Bagnoli, where he was deployed as a <a href="defensive%20midfielder">defensive midfielder</a>. In 1988, he moved to <a href="Juventus%20F.C.">Juventus</a>; during his time at the club, he played and scored in the <a href="1990%20UEFA%20Cup%20Final">1990 UEFA Cup Final</a>, helping Juventus to win the title over <a href="A.C.%20Fiorentina">Fiorentina</a>. He also won the <a href="1989%E2%80%9390%20Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a> that <a href="1989%E2%80%9390%20Serie%20A">season</a>, scoring the decisive goal in the final against <a href="A.C.%20Milan">Milan</a>, as well as another <a href="1992%E2%80%9393%20UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> title with the club in 1993. In 1994, he moved to Ascoli at the age of 31, only remaining with the club until November, before moving back to Como in 1995 for three seasons, playing in <a href="Serie%20B">Serie B</a> and <a href="Serie%20C1">Serie C1</a> with the club, before retiring in 1997, winning the <a href="Coppa%20Italia%20Serie%20C">Coppa Italia Serie C</a>. In total, he managed 300 appearances and 15 goals in Serie A, 65 appearances and 6 goals in Serie B, and 54 appearances in Serie C1. Following his retirement, he worked as a football coach.
International career.
Galia represented <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a> on three occasions under <a href="Arrigo%20Sacchi">Arrigo Sacchi</a>, all while taking part in the <a href="1992%20U.S.%20Cup">1992 U.S. Cup</a>. He also represented Italy at the <a href="Italy%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a>, where the team reached the semi-finals, finishing in fourth place.
